verses.text: Not to us, LORD, not to us, but to your name give glory, for your steadfast love and your truth.
verses.comment: The psalm opens with a denial of personal glory, seeking that all honor be directed to God alone for His enduring love and faithfulness. This devotional attitude reflects humility and the biblical ideal of giving God primary glory (cf. 1 Cor. 10:31).

verses.text: Why should the nations say, 'Where is their God?'
verses.comment: The psalmist voices the taunt of unbelieving nations questioning God's presence. This sets up a contrast between visible idolatry and the invisible, yet present, living God. Spiritual interpretation: Faith trusts even when God's action isn't immediately visible.

verses.text: Our God is in the heavens; he does whatever pleases him.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty is stressed; His transcendence contrasts with the limitations of idols. This ties to the Lord’s Prayer (Matt. 6:9), acknowledging God in heaven with authority over all.

verses.text: Their idols are silver and gold, the work of human hands.
verses.comment: False gods are man-made, highlighting their impotence compared to the living Creator. Literal and spiritual readings combine here; idolatry is both physical and allegorical (cf. 1 John 5:21: 'keep yourselves from idols').

verses.text: They have mouths, but do not speak; eyes, but do not see;
verses.comment: The psalm mocks idolatry: these objects cannot communicate or perceive. Contrasted with the prophetic God who speaks and watches over His people.

verses.text: They have ears, but do not hear; noses, but do not smell;
verses.comment: Continuing the polemic, idols lack capacity for relationship. This contrasts with the personal relationship God offers—He hears and receives prayers and sacrifices.

verses.text: They have hands, but do not feel; feet, but do not walk; they make no sound in their throat.
verses.comment: The total impotence of idols is stressed—unable to act or move. The living God acts in history and speaks through His prophets.

verses.text: Those who make them will become like them, and so will all who trust in them.
verses.comment: Idolatry leads to spiritual deadness. This foreshadows New Testament teaching: becoming like what we worship. Spiritual growth is found in true worship (cf. 2 Cor. 3:18, transformation by beholding God’s glory).

verses.text: Israel, trust in the LORD! He is their help and their shield.
verses.comment: A call to faith and reliance on God. Note the repetition throughout Scripture, urging Israel to trust not in idols or human strength but in the Lord alone.

verses.text: House of Aaron, trust in the LORD! He is their help and their shield.
verses.comment: Inclusion of the priestly line encourages those set apart for sacred service to place their confidence in God’s protection. The communal structure of worship is emphasized.

verses.text: You who fear the LORD, trust in the LORD! He is their help and their shield.
verses.comment: The invitation extends to all who revere God. This encompasses both Israel and new gentile worshippers, prefiguring the universal call to worship in Christ (see Rom. 3:29-30).

verses.text: The LORD has remembered us; he will bless us; he will bless the house of Israel; he will bless the house of Aaron;
verses.comment: God’s covenant faithfulness assures His people of blessing. This continuity in the biblical story points ahead to the blessing opened to all in the faith community through Christ.

verses.text: He will bless those who fear the LORD, both the small and the great.
verses.comment: God’s blessing is impartial to rank or status. Literal and spiritual readings encourage reverence regardless of one's place in the community. See also Acts 10:34: 'God shows no partiality.'

verses.text: May the LORD give you increase, you and your children!
verses.comment: The theme of generational blessing recurs. God’s plan is communal and family-centered, consistent throughout Scripture (cf. Gen. 17:7).

verses.text: May you be blessed by the LORD, who made heaven and earth.
verses.comment: Affirms the Creator as the source of all blessing. Divine authority underpins every favor and promise given.

verses.text: The heavens are the LORD’s heavens, but the earth he has given to mankind.
verses.comment: Distinction between divine and human realms—God's sovereignty, man's stewardship. Christ recapitulates and fulfills man’s vocation as the Second Adam (Romans 5:14-17).

verses.text: The dead do not praise the LORD, nor do any who go down into silence.
verses.comment: The psalm draws a sharp line between the living and dead in worship. Later revelation opens the hope of resurrection and eternal praise through Christ (John 11:25-26; Rev. 7:9-10).

verses.text: But we will bless the LORD from this time forth and forevermore. Praise the LORD!
verses.comment: Ends with a vow of perpetual worship. The community commits to praise now and eternally—a foreshadowing of the worship of the saints in glory. See Heb. 12:22-24 for the vision of everlasting worship.
